channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Says 50 Were Killed in Strikes on Four Syria Hospitals
item.description: Officials at the United Nations and Doctors Without Borders said missile strikes in north Syria hit four facilities, with children among the dead.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A destroyed hospital in Maarat al-Noaman in Idlib Province, Syria, on Monday, after it was hit by airstrikes.

item.title: The Opium War: Tasked With Combating Opium, Afghan Officials Depend on It
item.description: In a peaceful corner of Helmand Province, poppies grow in plain sight, directly taxed by a government ever more deeply involved in the drug trade.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan farmers harvested poppies last spring in the Nad Ali district of Helmand Province.

item.title: U.S.-Owned Plane Carrying Corpse and Cash Is Impounded in Zimbabwe
item.description: The cargo jet, transporting money for the South African Reserve Bank, was seized during a refueling stop after a body dripping blood was found on board.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: An Anti-Corruption Charade in Honduras
item.description: Instead of backing toothless investigations, the U.S. should use its financial leverage against political graft in Central America.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER MAIN
item.media:description: Protesters calling for the resignation of President Juan Orlando Hernández marched in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, last year.

item.title: Americans and Dutch Train Senegal Commandos as Fears of Terrorism Grow
item.description: The exercises come at a time of heightened worries after recent Qaeda attacks at luxury hotels in the capitals of Mali and Burkina Faso.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegalese commandos as they participated in a training exercise near St.-Louis, Senegal, on Friday.

item.title: Kashgar Journal: Silk Road Market Caters to Lovers of Acceleration, Handling and Plumage
item.description: The market fills with ethnic Uighurs engaged in a frenzied, mercantile display of traditional male bonding. The objects of their attention: pigeons.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pigeon market in Kashgar, China, in December. Devotees of the pastime claim that the Uighurs have been keeping the birds for more than a thousand years.

item.title: Anti-Gay Actions in Indonesia Threaten a Fragile Community
item.description: Recent recommendations aimed at chipping away at the social standing of lesbians and gays have caught most human rights activists in Jakarta by surprise.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY HUTTON
item.media:description: An official in Indonesia is pressuring instant messaging services to drop gay- and lesbian-themed emoticons.

item.title: Zika Virus in Colombia Presents Complicated Choice About Abortion
item.description: The illness appeared in the country too recently for most pregnant women who contracted it to determine the risk of birth defects.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marlenia Ortíz, center with blonde hair, at a camp for the homeless in Cúcuta, Colombia. She said that one of her five children had contracted Zika and that she feared the whole family would get the virus.

item.title: Ehud Olmert, Ex-Prime Minister of Israel, Begins Prison Sentence
item.description: In a video, Mr. Olmert acknowledged that he had “made mistakes,” but he insisted that he had done nothing criminal.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel, center, arrived at Maasiyahu Prison on Monday to begin his 19-month sentence.

item.title: Opposition Candidate Briefly Held Before Uganda’s Presidential Vote
item.description: Kizza Besigye, who is challenging President Yoweri Museveni for the presidency, had been arrested as he was holding a rally.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: Bodyguards piled on top of Kizza Besigye, the opposition leader, as the riot police fired tear gas in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: Syrian Officer Gave a View of War. ISIS Came, and Silence Followed.
item.description: Abu al-Majd, who fought with government forces, also struck up a relationship with Times correspondents. Then he was sent to Palmyra, and disappeared.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Syrian soldier at the ancient Temple of Baal in Palmyra, Syria, in March 2014, before the Islamic State overran the area. The group blew up the site last year.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Le procès Hissène Habré, un succès à ne pas répéter
item.description: Jamais dans une affaire de crimes contre l’humanité la voix des victimes n’aura été aussi dominante. Et l’Union africaine conclut : ne recommençons pas.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THIERRY CRUVELLIER
item.media:credit: Cemil Oksuz/Anadolu Agency, via Agence France-Presse
item.media:description: Des proches de victimes de l’ancien président tchadien Hissène Habré assistant à une séance du tribunal spécial cré pour le juger, à Dakar, au Sénégal.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Trial of Hissène Habré
item.description: Never in a trial for mass crimes have the victims' voices been so dominant. And the African Union is saying: Never again.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THIERRY CRUVELLIER
item.media:credit: Cemil Oksuz/Anadolu Agency, via Agence France-Presse
item.media:description: Relatives of victims of the former Chadian president attending a session of the special court set up to judge him, in Dakar, Senegal.

item.title: Rising Yen Adds to Abe’s Challenges as Japan’s Economy Contracts
item.description: The economic campaign that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe began three years ago, known as Abenomics, relied on a relatively weak currency.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: The Ginza neighborhood of Tokyo on Monday. The Japanese economy has contracted in five of the past 12 quarters, and for all of 2015 it grew an anemic 0.4 percent.

item.title: Nikita Kamayev, Ex-Head of Russian Antidoping Agency, Dies
item.description: The former executive, 52, apparently had a heart attack, becoming the second high official of the agency to die this month.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Nikita Kamayev, former director of the Russian antidoping agency, in Moscow in 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Legal Professionals, Under Limits at Home, Note Scalia’s Death
item.description: Several essays about the late American jurist were circulating in Chinese, including a paean by a justice on China’s Supreme People’s Court.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: At the United States Embassy in Beijing, the flag flew at half-staff in tribute to Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court justice who died over the weekend.

item.title: Jakob Denzinger, Suspected Nazi Prison Guard, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. Denzinger became a successful businessman in the United States after the war, but fled while under investigation by the Justice Department.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A portrait of Jakob Denzinger at his gravesite in Croatia in 2014.

item.title: Malawi Gets Its First Grammy Nomination, With Album by Prison Inmates
item.description: The work has been an unexpected boon for the tiny African nation and now goes up against the works of well-known artists in the world music category.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Members of the Zomba prison band performing last month at the maximum security institution in Zomba, Malawi.

item.title: In Mexican Slum, Pope Francis Laments Economic Gap
item.description: By coming to Ecatepec, one of the country’s largest, poorest and most violent cities, the pope placed himself at the center of Mexico’s identity crisis.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis warned against “a society of the few, and for the few” at a Mass in the Mexico City suburb of Ecatepec on Sunday.

item.title: Silao Journal: Pilgrimage in Mexico Keeps a Cowboy Tradition Alive
item.description: More than 3,000 people made this year’s three-day journey to a mountaintop statue of Jesus, hoping to find redemption, a promise of rain or just a connection to the past.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cowboys rode toward a Mass at the hill where the statue was built in the 1940s.
